Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Basics of fluid mechanics: hydrostatics, continuity, control volume analysis, Navier-Stokes, compressible and incompressible flow, dimensional analysis, etc. Taking this class also helped me develop better study patterns. The information was highly relevant to other classes in my major (G&G). So much of atmospheric and oceanic science is based on fluids!

It builds off of thermo a good amount, so having taken thermo before helps you do well. As the class title says, you learn about moving fluids. He has fun facts that help you relate the content to the real world, such as seeing whether driving upside down is possible and what speed you'd need to do so. It's a classic engineering course, so it's all about problem solving and understanding what you need to do in the problem, which isn't much different from any other engineering class you'll take.

Smooke's among the best STEM professors at Yale, the class is fair, Philip's a great TA, and you actually learn material. This class is mandatory if you're MENG, but if you're AMTH highly recommend as an elective.
I developed a pretty good intuition for the central concepts of fluid mechanics.
I learned how to make calculations related to fluids

This class is a rigorous introduction to fluid mechanics. We started with fluid statics and manometers, and then transitioned into fluid dynamics concepts that included control volume analysis, conservation laws of mass, energy, and momentum, Navier-Stokes equations, flow through pipes and ducts, and at the end of the term talked about irrotational flow, potential functions and stream functions, and incompressible flow.
I now have a moderate understanding of Fluid Mechanics.
The class gives you a very good understanding of the way that fluids move and different equations to describe this movement both in idealized and realistic scenarios.
I learned a lot of important mechanical engineering principles.
Problem solving, understanding fluid dynamics, which involves the movement of not just liquids but air. lots of airplane problems.
I learned a great deal about the properties of fluids.

I found this course to be very helpful in understanding the difficult concept of Fluid Mechanics. I found I have a strong understanding of both the derivations and applications of the formulas and concepts developed in the class. I also believe I have a firm understanding of the concepts to be tasked with a new problem and now how to solve it.
This class continued to develop my calculus and differential equations skills and how they apply in real life scenarios.
I learned basic concepts related to hydrostatics, control volume analysis, pipe flow, boundary layer theory, etc. that have taught me how to set up and approach real-life fluid mechanics problems.
You learn how to do figure out what fluids do. Generally, they move around and affect pressure and things. Pretty interesting
Good intro to fluid mechanics. You'll walk away with at least a good base knowledge of fluids
I gained a strong foundation in fluid mechanics.
Great practical and useful knowledge
hydrostatics, Bernoulli's equation, Navier-Stokes equations, a little bit of thermo, pretty good coverage of all the basics of fluids
I learned about fluid motion through pipes, incompressible and compressible fluids. Really interesting stuff.

General understanding of compressible and incompressible fluid mechanics, as well as the application of various equations to the analysis of compressible and incompressible fluid flow. When to assume compressible/incompressible fluid flow, how mass, momentum, and energy and transferred via fluid flow. Prof. Smooke also made a strong effort to tie the class to practical applications via real-world examples.
I learned about fluid mechanics and the different applications of fluids in an engineering environment.
How to apply basic understandings of physics and math to much more complex systems and understand fluid dynamics.
I gained an understanding of the mechanics of fluids. How they interact, their flow patterns, and their applications in the real world.
I feel like a got a lot better understanding of how piping systems would work and the parameters that affect, which is really useful for environmental engineering when designing reactor systems.
This class taught the basic ideas of many concept in fluid mechanics --- pretty essential if you're going to take any other G&G or engineering classes.

I learned a lot during this class. I thought it was well taught and I that problem sets and exams were fair. I do not know how useful all the information i learned will be in the future but what I needed from the class I got.

This course was a pretty standard mechanical engineering course, with a slightly greater emphasis on differential equations. Additionally, this gives a comprehensive interview of the mechanics and mathematics behind fluid mechanics, with some in-class derivations.
I actually learned quite a bit about fundamentals of fluid mechanics, and reinforced skills I learned in other math classes (multivariable calculus and differential equations).

A survey of basic fluid mechanic topics that ties closely to thermodynamics. Diff EQ was frequently used to derive key equations from simple laws, and would thus be fairly easy for someone with a good grasp of relevant maths topics. It definitely helped build a strong intuition for analyzing this kind of problems.
This was a really challenging course.
I learned about the basic equations of fluid flow including the Bernoulli and Navier-Stokes equations. I also learned about boundary layers and flow through pipes.

We learned about using hydrostatic equations, Navier-Stokes, the Bernoulli equation, and various conservation relationships, as well as simplifications and relationships between all of these different equations. We also learned about boundary layer theory, as well as various equations for engines and pumps.
Honestly, not much comes to mind.  If anything, I feel I've gained an improved ability to solve complex-seeming engineering problems beyond the basic physics level.
Turbulence and isentrophic  flow

My only criticisms of this course are that the lecture room made it very difficult to see the board. Sometimes the handwriting was difficult to read, I think the classroom made it worse. Maybe it would help if more often, a pause was taken to field any questions and make sure people are following what is being taught. Some more examples from the atmosphere and ocean would be really neat as well, but I can understand the choice not to include them as most students are engineers. Would be interesting though.

He held occasional friday classes, which were no fun at the time but great overall because that meant no classes after Thanksgiving break. He also did 3 tests instead of 2 midterms and a final (so not cumulative). The last day of classes was a lot because of this and finals in other classes on the same day, but I wouldn't change it, as it means you're done with the class before reading period. 

He has discussed doing a flipped classroom, but I honestly don't think it'd be as conducive to understanding the material. Lecture could get confusing sometimes, as any lecture can, but the book and just studying/doing problems were helpful in clearing things up. The TAs were also great at answering questions. 

The one thing that vaguely scared me was how well people did on the exams, as I worried about the grade distribution in the end. I'm not sure how it'll turn out, but the grades were more spread out with each exam. His exams were fair, and if you studied and did practice problems, you should do exceedingly well in the class. 

One weakness for some and strength for others is that people who have taken Thermodynamics before had a significant advantage over everyone else. This mainly applied only to the first exam, but it also came into effect some in the 3rd exam. There's no real way around this, but I'd suggest taking thermo first.

Smooke's among the best STEM professors at Yale, the class is fair, Philip's a great TA, and you actually learn material. This class is mandatory if you're MENG, but if you're AMTH highly recommend as an elective.

I thought the exam structure was great - three 90 minute midterms - and took off a lot of stress, allowing us to focus on studying more specific material at a time. I do think the homework could be a bit more challenging as I often felt I could work through the problems without really understanding the concepts. Also, I don't think a flipped classroom is a good idea.

Great course and great professor. Smooke doesnt like the textbook very much, but I found it very helpful personally. It was a little difficult to follow all the lectures - I could benefit from longer explanations of what we are deriving and where we are deriving it from before jumping into the math.

I really enjoyed the structure of the course. We met every other Friday to get ahead on the lectures, and we had three big exams (of equal weight), so we actually finished the course before reading period. This course was taught exceptionally well.
This course is very well organized, tests are fair. Lectures are sometimes boring and sometimes super engaging it really depended. This time slot was a huge hassle for me though.

I enjoyed the class overall; there was not too much homework and generally the problem sets were very representative of the exams. Some subjects were kind of brushed over and ended up being more important than expected such as the work flow, but that was rare.

Professor Smooke is the highlight of this course. He is seriously amazing and makes difficult course material easier to understand. I actually looked forward to going to fluids twice a week and both psets and exams were fair and exactly what he promised they would be. If he warns you that it's going to be a difficult test, it will be.
I think the course could have been improved if the professor taught a bit slower and if the practice problems and solutions were put up earlier.
I loved professor Smooke, but there could have been more examples done in class rather than derivations.

The course I feel was a good balance between conceptual understandings of the derivations of integral formulas and also applications of these formulas. It was not too theoretical but at the same time there weren't too many applications so that you could only solve problems if they were in a similar vein to problems done in class. The problem sets were reasonable and questions pertained to information taught in class .
Sometimes the theoretical sides of the class can be a bit difficult to translate into the application side of things but this is the difficulty of all engineering classes.

I really liked meeting four extra times (on Fridays) over the course of the semester, since it allowed us to finish the material early and gave us more flexibility with homework deadlines and the third exam. I also really appreciated how Prof. Smooke went through both derivations and practice problems (there could have been some more of these) in class, as well as incorporated many real-life examples of the concepts we touched upon in class. The course could be improved by having more practice problems throughout the semester, especially prior to exams. For the exams, posting sample problems/tests and their solutions earlier would also be helpful, as most of our practice material was only distributed very close to the exam itself.

Professor Smooke did a great job lecturing. A lot of time was spent on derivations, which some people don't like but I really value. The TAs were lacking, however, and didn't usually provide great direction.
Smooke is a great lecturer
I felt the class was very organized, and I had all the resources I needed to understand the material. It went at a good pace, and I was generally interested and engaged in the class.
Smooke rocked it! Keep teaching forever please
I really like the structure of this class and wouldn't change anything, except for I wish that there were formal review sessions before the exams

This class is easily the best one offered in the mechanical engineering track. Professor Smooke actually does a great job teaching everything, and brings cool videos and examples into class that keep everyone engaged.
Great Lecturer, needs more practice materials for the exams i believe

Strengths are the Professor for sure; Smooke is the best STEM professor I have had at Yale without question. His lecture format, although fast-paced, is easy to follow and he takes time to answer individual questions. The textbook was also useful as the course follows it quite closely. Weaknesses were perhaps the variability among problem sets and exams, as some homeworks were quite short and straightforward while others took hours on end and required you to look up additional equations, data, etc. The first and third exams also seemed significantly more straightforward than the second, so the pacing of material could perhaps have been refined a bit.

strength- very fair, very well taught
weakness- went a little fast
Great course.
The course was very focused and always started each segment by learning the proper derivations. This was helpful in that we were provided a better base from which to learn the material.
Smooke is a good lecturer and a chill guy. Fluids isn't the most riveting material but he made it interesting though real world examples in class.

I think it was organized very well and very manageably, but I couldn't make any of the friday classes because I had a lab class during that time, so to improve that I would provide more supporting materials on canvas for those friday lectures. I definitely missed some bonus points because they referenced things brought up on fridays.

The applications of fluid mechanics are super interesting, although Smooke did a little on applications, I feel like we could have done more interesting examples. Overall the material is pretty dense and boring, maybe if the class was personalized a little more rather than being taught out of the textbook it would be more interesting.

I liked how this class ran. I really like the three midterm system. I wish classes could be taken just a bit slower as professor Smooke talks really fast, and it could sometimes be overwhelming but that is about it.

Smooke was very engaging in lecture, even though the hour and fifteen minute time slot made the class seem drawn out near the end. I thought that the derivations in class were nice to at least know, but there could possibly be more time for example problems to gain a better understanding of the practical material.

This class had good lectures, although a bit on the fast side. There were adequate examples and fun applications that maintained interest in subject. Problem sets were reasonable, though did not always reflect things we learned in class. Exams were very fair and feedback clear. The only thing I would request is practice exams posted a little earlier. I loved that we finished early by having get-ahead classes too! It made my finals period much better!

Strengths: Professor Smooke's unrivaled experience in teaching this course helped a lot. He really knows what he's talking about, and progresses in a way that makes logical sense. Homework was fair, and helps were available from both of the TAs.

Weaknesses: The classroom was terrible... poor visibility to the board, added by Prof. Smooke's inadequate understanding of classroom equipment made trying to learn visually a challenge. He's also a super fast lecturer, without posting lecture notes after class.
No classes on Friday as an athlete I could not attend
A lot of derivation in class, but the PSETs tend to be practical, so a better connection can be formed between what is taught and what is expected.

Smooke was a great professor and clearly cared about his students. Sometimes the notes were hard to read during lecture and at times it felt like the homework covered material that we had never even talked about in class, but overall this was a fair course.

Smooke is a great guy, and the class was very well organized. I don't think really think anything should be changed in that respect, you might get some comments proposing structural changes, but I bet there is no individual change that the majority of students would agree with.

There are some practical issues though- it was really hard to read the board.  The combination of the room, and Smooke's handwriting made it way too easy to get lost, which in the middle of some long fluids derivation could really kill your attention.  Also, such a large class really needs more TFs.

I think the course did a good job teaching fluid mechanics. For me it would have been help if at the beginning of the chapter Professor Smooke would take a bit more time to summarize the key ides in the upcoming chapter and why they are important. For the boundary layer chapter, for example, this could include spending more time describing/giving examples of what a boundary layer is and reviewing why we need to treat them separately using boundary layer equations.
I also think the class would have benefited from going a tiny bit slower because it was sometimes hard to even copy Prof. Smooke's work from the board concurrently with the lecture. I liked the examples in class as they provided useful information about applications of the material covered in class. I really liked the setup with 3 midterms and no final as it helped break down the class into more manageable chunks an keep up with work.

The only weakness I could think of for this course would be the timing of our last midterm; there was kind of a long gap between our last class and the midterm, and it would have been helpful to either have the midterm a bit earlier or have some kind of review just because of the time that had passed. It would also be very helpful to have access to lecture recordings, because sometimes Professor Smooke says something really helpful but doesn't write it down, and it can be easy to miss when writing notes in class. Not having recordings wasn't a weakness, but it could be helpful for students to have.
Lectures were very well-organized, and Professor Smooke selected textbook readings that aligned closely with the in-class material - which was very useful for completing problem sets and studying.

Weaknesses: lecture style was boring, followed textbook too closely, labored through boring proofs instead of going further into applications (it is an engineering class so I was hoping to see more applications, detailed questions, project based questions)

Strengths: included fun bits of trivia to break up the lecture a bit, went through examples, exams were straightforward and matched lecture/HW material well.

Fluid Mechanics is a required course for several majors. For G&G it is a core class and deservedly so. So much of what you learn in this class will be applicable to your climate and oceanography courses. I would recommend taking it before or at least at the same time as you take Physical Oceanography/Physics of Weather and Climate and other upper level courses in the major. MENG 361 is a well-taught course with a superb professor and excellent TAs (Kevin amd Philip) who are patient and extremely experienced with the course material. The organization of the course also really facilitated my learning and understanding of the material. Unlike other STEM classes I've taken in the past, the problem sets were conducive to understanding as well as retention, while also being fairly challenging. You will not spend an unreasonable amount of time on the homework; none of it is extraneous. The exams are fair as well. If you put in the time and effort, you can certainly do well. This is the best STEM course I've taken at Yale so far. I really enjoyed it and learned so much.

Most people are in this class because they have to take it, but I think the structure was nice. He occasionally held Friday classes (3 or 4 throughout the semester) so that we would finish the material early. What this meant was we didn't have a full class after Thanksgiving break--just one short class to finish everything up, turn in the homework, and see him before the last exam. Additionally, he does 3 tests rather than 2 midterms and a final, which aren't cumulative. This made the last day of classes vaguely stressful as other classes also had exams then, but makes final period way easier. His exams are fair, and if you've put in the time, you should do well. 

If you've taken Thermodynamics before fluids, you'll have a huge advantage over everyone else in the first (and 3rd) exam. This really helped me do well in fluids, although it could be said that maybe doing fluids first would have made thermo easier, which is definitely a tougher course. The easy material in thermo is gone over in fluids, so take what you will of that info and decide which to do first.

Smooke's among the best STEM professors at Yale, the class is fair, Philip's a great TA, and you actually learn material. This class is mandatory if you're MENG, but if you're AMTH highly recommend as an elective.
it's a good class with interesting material, but I probably wouldn't take it for fun
This is a fantastic course. Fluid mechanics is such an important topic, so even if you do not need to take this class I would highly recommend it.

Absolutely do not take if you don't have to. No matter your interest level, it is not interesting or engaging enough to warrant taking without the requirement. I barely showed up to class and just read wikipedia pages, the textbook, and Nasa websites and did very well pretty easily.
If it counts for your major, or you're just really interested in the class definitely take it. Prof. Smooke is a great teacher and most of the class tends to do well as a result.
One of the better courses I have taken in engineering at Yale.
Only if you take it with Smooke!!

This course is required for many engineering majors. If you don't need to take this, the benefits of this course would just be understand fluid dynamic principles, so I wouldn't recommend unless it's required. 

The tests are pretty straight forward. Just follow the notes from class and if you listen during lecture, you'll even get some extra credit trivia questions right on the exams. Professor Smooke is great, I wish he would sometimes slow down a bit, but he's clear and the tests are very fair. 

I had trouble in the beginning of the year because i just did problems from the homework and textbook. While those are helpful for understanding concepts, he will mostly test on example problems and concepts from the notes.
You are probably only taking this course if it is required for your major. However, it does provide useful information about real world engineering applications.

I would recommend this course to a student if they wanted to see what a high level engineering course is like but I wouldn't recommend it if they didn't have to take it as the information is fairly major specific.
I am unsure if I would recommend this course to non-stem Yalies, as it seems very niche to engineers- who have to take the course anyways.

I would definitely recommend fluid mechanics! I took it as an elective for BME and was surprised to find that it was a much more enjoyable experience than some of the required classes Ive taken for my major (fluids actually turned out to be extremely applicable and helpful for the BME biomechanics class as well). I think every engineering class should be like this  an appropriate mix of both derivations and real-life examples in lecture, a solid textbook that supplements lecture material and explains concepts clearly, practice problems that correspond well with the material that actually appears on exams, and TAs who make themselves available and provide helpful feedback throughout the semester. Prof. Smooke was a very clear lecturer and was also very accommodating of our schedules.

If you have to take it, then you have to take it. If you're considering this as an elective, then I guess it really depends on your interest. Smooke was a great teacher, but I don't think I'd want to take it with anyone else. He's entertaining and brings outside info in. Pay attention tho, he has extra credit related to fun facts he says in class.
It's required for most engineering majors here, but beyond that, probably not.

It was a solid fluid mechanics class. I feel like I have a strong foundation on the subject, but was never overwhelmed by what we were learning. The class is very organized and Smooke was a great prof!
Fluid Mechanics is fun and painless with Smooke. He often asks for feedback and is always trying to improve himself as a teacher, which is hard considering how awesome he already is.

Fluids is very useful for anything you want to do in the real world, as well as some other cool classes at Yale. You're probably taking it because you have to, but you will enjoy the hell out of it. If Yale classes were memes, this one would be a cute doggo. 10/10 would recommend
Only if you are engineering major, theres no need to take it otherwise
You're probably only going to take this if you have to, but if you have a strong foundation in calculus and are interested in some applied physics, it's a great course.
If you have to take it for your major! Otherwise, it's a little hard to be engaged in.
Great class, not too much more, and very interesting.
I am a BME, so this course wasn't required for me. I would still recommend it, as I learned relatively interesting and useful skills that are relevant across several engineering disciplines.
I wouldn't if you don't need to take it just because it takes a lot of prior thinking in an engineering mindset, but if you have to take it I think you'd really enjoy it.

If you're taking this course, it is most likely because it is a requirement. The material is pretty boring, but the course isn't bad overall, so I would still recommend it. It is important to know for other subjects in G&G, engineering, astro, etc.
If you're looking to take a Mechanical Engineering course, I would definitely recommend this course, especially if it's taught by Prof. Smooke.
This class was interesting and useful, I'd recommend it even if you aren't required to take it for your major, especially if you can count it as an elective.

I would definitely recommend this course! Prof. Smooke is truly a great professor and person. I took this course because my major cancelled a core requirement a bit last minute and I needed a last minute elective for my major. This class was very manageable and taught well. Prof. Smooke is one of the most accessible professors at Yale and I am so happy that he is becoming Dean of Engineering!
Take it if you have any interest in engineering or design. It gives you great insight into flows and forces associated with fluids. A great course for mechanical engineers and non-majors alike.
The curve is insane and people do so well, I don't know how, so if you know you will struggle with the material try avoiding it.

If you can take fluids with Smooke, take it!  The class was well organized, with 3 midterms covering a 1/3 of the course and no final.  Smooke is a great guy, and sprinkled in lots of cool details throughout the course.

This course provides a great introduction to fluid mechanics and I would highly recommend it to other students. Make sure to pay attention from the beginning though because it seems deceptively simple at first but picks up rapidly. It's very easy to fall behind and spend a lot of time in class confused. You learn about very cool applications of fluid mechanics to airplanes and rockets.

Fluid Mechanics is a great class; Professor Smooke is probably my favorite professor in all of Yale. I really wish I had been a MechE major just so I could take more of his classes. 

Class is generally pretty engaging, with lots of real-world examples and videos to go along with concepts (although admittedly, derivations are pretty dull to learn). Smooke is also just a really nice and fun person, and I looked forward to this class every time. 

Homework is straight from the book, and it's easy to find explanations if you don't understand. Exam questions can be a little tricky, particularly if you don't have much background with thermodynamics (apparently a lot of material was review for MechE majors; not so much for BME). 

Although it isn't part of the course listing, there are some Friday classes to help get ahead of the typical midterm/final schedule; I actually really appreciated these, and we were done with new material by Thanksgiving. 

I would definitely recommend this for BME students looking for an enjoyable elective credit.
This course is no fun, it ends up being largely self-taught from a subpar textbook.  I left with very little intuitive understanding of how fluid mechanics actually works.
Yes, it's very fundamental
